KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Trilla Terminal
Mattoon, Illinois

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  KNC¿s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the KNC EHS&T Management System, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Trilla Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by KNC that supply anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest farming area where it is used primarily as a fertilizer.  At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on trucks for distribution.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Trilla Terminal in amounts above threshold quantity.  Propane is stored at the facility; however, it is used strictly as a fuel and is therefore exempt from RMP reporting pursuant to 40 CFR 68.126.  The terminal is subject to the Prevention Program/Program 3 requirements. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards include:

¿Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and reg

ulations. 
¿Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
¿Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
¿Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The Trilla Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and constant emphasis on safety have helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

¿Minimizing the possibility that flare combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted by having continuous pilots.
¿Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in power supply to the process control system and the flare system by having a backup power generator.
¿Providing emergency shutdown buttons at the truck loading area that can be activated by KNC personnel or the truck driver in case of an ammonia release.
¿Installing safety interlocks to stop product movement upon low pressurization.
¿Installing seal fail switches which stop product movement in the event of a pump seal failure.
¿Installing cameras to monitor the facility locally or from remote locations.
¿Providing emergency air escape packs at critical points throughout the facility.
¿Conducting preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program to help ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
¿Requiring trucks to have a brake interlock system that helps prevent a truck driver from driving away before the loading arm is properly disconne

cted.
¿Providing ammonia sensors in the process areas and on the property to detect ammonia and activate the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition monitoring system if the threshold for ammonia is exceeded.
¿Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety.


Five-Year Accident History

Within the last five years there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.


 
Emergency Response Program

The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Trilla Terminal with the Coles County Emergency Management Agency and the Charleston and Mattoon Fire Departments.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Coles County Sheriff and, as appropriate, the Sarah Bush Lincoln Hospital, Ameren CIPS (the utility company), and the Illinois State Highway Patrol.  The Trilla Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the EHS&T Management System, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

¿The Management of Change provisions are designed to ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
¿The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, t

hereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
¿The Mechanical Integrity provisions are designed to ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program. 

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the terminal include:

¿Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is periodically evaluated for improvements.
¿An ongoing dialogue with the Coles County Emergency Management Director or his designee will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Coles County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county.  The terminal coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
